description: From Medieval Latin infuriatus (“enraged”), past participle of infurio (“to enrage”), from Latin furia (“rage, fury, frenzy”), perhaps via Italian infuriato.

adjectives.description: infuriate (comparative more infuriate, superlative most infuriate)

entries.meaning: (now rare) Filled with, characterized by or expressing fury.

verbs.description: infuriate (third-person singular simple present infuriates, present participle infuriating, simple past and past participle infuriated)

entries.meaning: To make furious or mad with anger; to fill with fury.
